Award.AwardTitle: Computer Science Colorado Learning and Identity Collaborative (CS-CLIC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Colorado Education Initiative (CEI), in collaboration with McREL International (McREL), proposes a project -- the Computer Science Colorado Learning and Identity Collaborative (CS-CLIC) -- to work with educators at eight high schools located throughout Colorado on understanding the importance of engaging a diverse audience of students in Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (APCSP), understanding and using strategies to do so, and improving their use of evidence-based practices for effective student learning in the classroom. CS-CLIC's professional development will dramatically increase equitable access to rigorous computer science (CS) coursework, increasing number and diversity of students who see CS as relevant, possible, and important to them, enroll in APCSP, and earn qualifying scores on the APCSP exam.

CS-CLIC will employ an iterative Networked Improvement Community (NIC) structure to co-design and refine professional development (PD) and targeted recruiting materials focused on the problem of practice: Students, and, particularly historically underrepresented students, do not perceive rigorous CS coursework as important, possible, or relevant to their lives. Working together with classroom teachers, CS-CLIC researchers will develop, implement, and test strategies to improve recruitment and retention based on the Identity-Based Motivation model, building on an existing Colorado Legacy School effort that attracts historically underrepresented students into AP courses in other STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computer Science Colorado Learning and Identity Collaborative (CS-CLIC) used an improvement science approach to increase student access to and success in advanced placement Computer Science Principles coursework in seven rural high schools, with the goal of identifying successful practices to share nationwide—especially for minority students. An important component of improvement science is implementing Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycles to focus collaborative data use and iterative improvement. CS-CLIC’s team of researchers and educators focused PDSAs on topics such as metacognitive strategies and reciprocal teaching. These PDSAs were all designed to address the following problem of practice: Students, and particularly historically underrepresented students, do not perceive rigorous CS coursework as important, possible, or relevant.

This award funded professional learning and supports for a cohort seven educators representing seven rural schools across Colorado. This included participating in a week-long Advanced Placement Summer Institute, a two-day mock reading in the spring, and professional learning in five areas: 1) creating an inclusive classroom culture, 2) setting high student expectations, 3) communicating the relevance of computer science, 4) mastering computer science pedagogical content knowledge, and 5) designing and implementing PDSAs. Additionally, it provided financial support for students taking the advanced placement exam, student study sessions to prepare for the advanced placement exam, teacher stipends for participation in activities, and reimbursement of travel costs for teachers to attend professional learning sessions, including peer observations. All participating teachers used computer science curriculum from Code.org.

This project produced a theory of change hypothesizing the relationship between the three components of the educational model (classroom instruction, professional learning, and school and district systems and processes) and increased student outcomes. Additional products included a blog and an article (submitted to Principal Leadership). Several conference presentations were planned, but canceled because of COVID-19.
